header.title: The Watcher, No. 3
authors: N.Z. Voice of the Left-Hand Path

central_thesis: This issue of 'The Watcher' champions a radical interpretation of the Left-Hand Path, specifically aligning with Setian philosophy, emphasizing individual evolution (Xeper) and advocating for eugenic measures and strict retributive justice as essential for societal quality. It critiques perceived weaknesses in mainstream liberalism and certain factions of LaVeyan Satanism while asserting a distinct, intellectually rigorous, and genetically focused approach to Satanism and social order.

structure_content.summary: This section posits that societal crime escalation is due to 'liberalism' and 'Christian slush of tolerance.' It rejects social engineering and advocates for eugenic measures, including sterilization and capital punishment, based on the premise that crime, delinquency, and intelligence are primarily genetic. It cites a study by Mednick, Gabrielli, and Hutchings supporting the genetic basis of criminality and calls for a return to 'Nature's law of genetic selection' to eliminate 'genetic garbage' and create a 'quality population.'

structure_content.chapter_title: PRINCE OF DARKNESS IN POLYNESIA : 1000 BCE
structure_content.summary: This article speculatively links the Egyptian deity Set ('Prince of Darkness') to ancient Polynesian cultures, particularly Hawaii, via Egyptian sea-farers. It suggests Egyptians explored regions as far as Indonesia, Australia, NZ, and Hawaii, citing findings like Egyptian coins in NZ and petroglyphs and artifacts in Australia and Hawaii depicting Egyptian symbols (ankh cross, scarab, Set in dog form, Nephthys, funerary designs). It highlights a 1963 observation by Dr. Gwyn Griffiths on the Egyptian authenticity of Hawaiian inscriptions.

This piece details the founding of the Temple of Set in 1975 CE by Dr. Michael Aquino and others, who resigned from the Church of Satan in protest of Anton LaVey's commercialization. It defines Set as an ancient Egyptian deity representing 'psychecentric consciousness' and the origin of 'Hebraic Satan.' The Temple's philosophy centers on individual psyche development, or 'Xeper' (becoming/coming into being), as a path to self-divinity, rejecting collective consciousness. It describes itself as a non-dogmatic forum for 'cooperative philosophers and magicians,' not 'docile followers,' and provides membership details.

This section features correspondence, primarily from G. Escott of the 'Werewolf Order' and Michael A. Aquino. Escott criticizes 'The Watcher' for supporting 'drug abuser Aleister Crowley' and 'child molester Michael Aquino,' and for promoting 'liberal-humanistic ideologies' contrary to the 'rational ideas presented in The Satanic Bible.' He asserts the Werewolf Order's 'ideological purity' for 'radical Satanic dominion.' Aquino, in response, defends the Temple of Set against Escott's 'libelous' 'child molester' allegations, clarifies the Temple's distinction from the current Church of Satan (which he deems a 'LaVey spaniel kennel'), and affirms Setian philosophy's belief in deity and self-evolution, contrasting it with LaVey's secularism. Other letters offer general praise for 'The Watcher's' content and mission.

Reviews are provided for 'Witches text' by Colin Wilson (a history of witchcraft and occultism covering shamans, Merlin, Knights Templar, Kabbalah, Golden Dawn, Crowley, modern wicca, Church of Satan) and 'The Aleister Crowley Scrapbook' by Sandy Robertson (a collection of photos, memoirs, art, press articles, and an exploration of Crowley's legacy including OTOs, LaVey's Church of Satan, Temple of Set, and influence on rock music).

key_concepts.definition: A philosophical and magical path emphasized by 'The Watcher' and its associated groups, characterized by the pursuit of individual power, self-deification, and the rejection of conventional moral and social norms (e.g., 'Christian slush of tolerance'). It advocates for a rigorous, non-dogmatic, and often anti-liberal stance.

A societal reform program advocated in 'CRIME & PUNISHMENT,' based on the belief that crime and social ills are genetically determined. It proposes 'genetic selection,' sterilization, and capital punishment to eliminate 'genetic garbage' and foster a 'quality population,' asserting this as a 'Nature's law of genetic selection' rather than social engineering.

A distinct Satanic philosophy originating from the Egyptian deity Set, founded by Dr. Michael Aquino after a schism with Anton LaVey's Church of Satan. Its core tenet is 'Xeper' â€“ the evolution of the individual psyche ('the 'real you' of your conscious intelligence') towards self-divinity, explicitly rejecting 'universal consciousness' or merging with an external entity. It operates as a non-dogmatic forum for 'cooperative philosophers and magicians.'

An Egyptian term adopted by the Temple of Set, meaning 'to come into being' or 'to become.' It represents the central process of Setian philosophy: the deliberate exercise of individual intelligence and will to evolve one's 'psychecentric consciousness' towards its own divinity.

The core concept of individual identity and intelligence in Setian philosophy, referred to as 'the 'real you'.' The development and elevation of this individual consciousness is the primary focus of Setian practice, distinguishing it from paths that seek to dissolve or merge the self.

An 'elite Satanic militia' led by G. Escott, described as dedicated to 'radical Satanic dominion' and adhering to a strict standard of 'ideological purity.' This group criticizes other Satanic factions, including the Temple of Set and those influenced by Crowley, for perceived deviations from the 'rational ideas presented in The Satanic Bible' (Anton LaVey's work) and for 'liberal-humanistic ideologies.'

practical_system.description: The primary practical system outlined is Setianism, focusing on the individual's spiritual and intellectual development (Xeper). This involves the 'deliberate exercise of the intelligence and will' to evolve one's 'psychecentric consciousness' towards self-divinity. It is presented as a non-dogmatic path for 'philosophers and magicians' to communicate and cooperate in their personal evolution, rather than a system of collective rituals or worship. Complementary to this, the 'CRIME & PUNISHMENT' article implicitly advocates for a societal 'practical system' based on eugenics, involving 'genetic selection,' sterilization, and capital punishment, viewed as a natural law to ensure a 'quality population' and reduce crime.
tools: Philosophical study and cooperation (for Setians). For societal 'eugenics system': legislative/enforcement mechanisms for genetic selection, sterilization, and capital punishment (implied).
rituals: Deliberate exercise of intelligence and will for individual psyche evolution (Xeper).
No specific ceremonial rituals detailed, but emphasis is on individual, internal transformation rather than communal rites.

relevant_quotes.text: Since liberalism ascended to the control of our society and politically applied the Christian slush of tolerance and brotherly love to the dregs of humanity, our society has witnessed an escalation of crime year by year.
one does not achieve a quality society if the constituent parts of that society comprise an increasing number of genetic garbage.

Clearly eugenic measures are long overdue, and are the key to reducing crime and many other social ills. Habitual criminals are likely to be the product of their genetic inheritance, more so than any alleged social disadvantage. Sterilization and capital punishment are in order.
Set, the original Prince of Darkness, was being honoured with petroglyphs on boulders in Hawaii as far back as 3000 years ago by Egyptian sea-farers.

The Temple of Set was incorporated in 1975CE, when Dr Michael Aquino and the majority of the priesthood of the Church of Satan resigned in protest against Anton LaVey's decision to redesign the C/S 'as a non-functional vehicle for his personal expression and financial income.'

The Temple's philosophy is based on the development and contribution of the individual psyche 'the 'real you' of your conscious intelligence,' rejecting the aim of other religions to melt the psyche into oblivion of a 'universal consciouness.'

'The second premise of the Temple is that the psychecentric consciousness can evolve towards its own divinity through deliberate exercise of the intelligence and will, a process of becoming or coming into being' (Egyptian=Xeper).

The Werewolf Order stands in strict opposition to all of these practices, liberal-humanistic ideologies or in the worst case, The Temple of Shit (sic), even a juvenile belief in a diety. All of these beliefs contradict the rational ideas presented in The Satanic Bible by Anton La Vey as well as the philosophy of the Werewolf order.

How different it is from the authentic (I-X) Church of Satan, whose membership there was a climate of mutual courtesy, respect, and trust , similar to that of the Temple of Set today - unsurpising after all, since we are the original Church of Satan continued.

RW's referral to me as a 'child molester' in a letter to you is a clear act of libel, which I shall file against the eventual but unlikely possibility that RW may someday be financially worth the attention of my attorneys.

critical_analysis.relevance: This document is highly relevant for researchers in Western Esotericism and Occultism, providing primary source material on the internal dynamics, ideological schisms, and socio-political engagements of various Satanic and Left-Hand Path groups in the late 20th century. It offers a unique insight into the Temple of Set's foundational philosophy (Xeper) and its distinction from LaVeyan Satanism, as well as the emergence of other radical groups like the Werewolf Order. Furthermore, its controversial advocacy for eugenics and harsh justice within an occult framework highlights a fringe intersection of esoteric beliefs with extreme socio-political ideologies, offering a critical case study for understanding the broader implications of such movements.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of practitioners and academics in Western Esotericism, Left-Hand Path philosophies, and Satanic studies, particularly those interested in the Temple of Set's specific doctrines, its historical context, and its relationship with other occult currents. Additionally, it would appeal to individuals intrigued by fringe political ideologies that merge with occult or pseudo-scientific (e.g., eugenics) frameworks, as well as those interested in the history of counter-cultural or radical thought in New Zealand and beyond.
